description:
Poecilia latipinna, commonly known as the sailfin molly, is a species of freshwater fish that belongs to the family Poeciliidae. It is native to the coastal regions of the Gulf of Mexico, from southern Texas to the Yucat√°n Peninsula in Mexico.

The sailfin molly is a small fish, typically reaching a length of around 5-8 inches (12-20 cm). Its distinguishing feature is the large, sail-like dorsal fin, which is more prominent in males. The body shape is laterally compressed, and the coloration varies from silvery-gray to dark brown, with some individuals displaying iridescent patterns.

These fish are known for their unique reproductive strategy, which involves internal fertilization and live birth. Females can store sperm from multiple males and give birth to multiple broods of fry throughout the year. The sailfin molly is an important component of the aquatic ecosystems in its native range, serving as a food source for larger predatory fish and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the region.

Due to its adaptability and popularity in the aquarium trade, the sailfin molly has been introduced to various regions around the world, where it can sometimes become an invasive species, competing with native fish populations and disrupting the local ecosystem.
